l1.label: The text that follows is based on a recruitment negotiation, whereby an employer is discussing the different issues that have come up in a potential employee’s employment contract. Match the following phrases with the correct type of issue:

choices.label: In a salary negotiation, the negotiators found that there were certain issues, such as the starting date and salary, that they had opposing views on. These fall under the ___________ category.
The employer had to discuss and find a mutually beneficial solution to the issue of the employee’s moving expenses. This issue was a/an ___________.
Both the employer and employee agreed that the employee would be best suited for the London office, rather than the office in Manchester. This issue was a/an _______________.

l2.label: The main difference between an integrative and a distributive negotiation is the number of issues attached to them. Distributive negotiation can have a maximum of two issues, while  integrative negotiation can account for more than two issues.

choices.label: Incorrect. Distributive negotiation – in which the size of the pie is fixed – typically involves only a single issue. These types of negotiations focus on single-issue bargaining strategies. However, if you are a skilled negotiator, you can unbundle existing issues and add issues to the negotiation. Adding issues increases the size of the pie, in which case the negotiation will become integrative.

Correct, well done. Distributive negotiation – in which the size of the pie is fixed – typically involves only a single issue. Integrative negotiations are those that involve multiple issues, because adding and unbundling issues increases the size of the pie.

Steven needs the lemon to make lemonade and Abigail needs the lemon to make icing for her cake. After much dispute, they decide to cut the lemon in half, so that they can each use part of it.

choices.label: Incorrect, please try again. In this example, the children’s interest is their use of the lemon. However, the only issue they are negotiating is the single lemon. They are not trying to bring more issues to the table to expand the pie.
Correct, well done. The children are looking at this situation in terms of a single issue: they both need a lemon. Their agreement to cut it in half is a means of dividing up a fixed resource.

Incorrect, please try again. In this example, the children’s interest is their use of the lemon. However, the only issue they are negotiating is the single lemon. In this scenario, the children’s interests are not compatible, as there is only one resource on the table and they both value it to an equal degree.

l5.label: The fixed-pie fallacy refers to the tendency to think there is a static amount of resources that needs to be split between those involved in a negotiation,  which means that the only way one can get more is by taking it from the other.

choices.label: Correct, well done. The fixed-pie fallacy refers to the common assumption that negotiators are negotiating over a fixed amount of resources. If resources are (assumed to be) fixed, one person’s gain will be another’s loss. However, skilled negotiators can combat this fallacy by unbundling the issue or adding issues to the negotiation, thereby expanding the pie.

Incorrect. The fixed-pie fallacy refers to the common assumption that negotiators are negotiating over a fixed amount of resources. If resources are (assumed to be) fixed, one person’s gain will be another’s loss. In this case, skilled negotiators can counteract this fallacy by unbundling the issue or adding issues to the negotiation, thereby expanding the pie.

components.General feedback: In any negotiation, people can balance out different issues, and order their different priorities, in order to increase the pie and highlight package deals that could generate the most joint surplus. If two parties have opposing interests in an issue, that is an example of a distributive issue (e.g. the starting date and salary in the scenario). Since both parties had to discuss the issue of moving expenses to find a mutually beneficial agreement, this issue can be categorised as an integrative issue, as finding trade-offs in this instance would help them reach an agreement. Both the employer and employee believed that it was best to be based in London rather than Manchester, which is a compatible issue.
